sourcing.instructions: B (Boron powder) from chemical supply companies (e.g., Sigma-Aldrich); Nb (Niobium powder) from specialty metal suppliers; Ru (Ruthenium powder) from precious metal suppliers; Sb (Antimony powder) from metal suppliers; Sc (Scandium powder) from chemical suppliers.
steps: B (Boron powder) from chemical supply companies (e.g., Sigma-Aldrich); Nb (Niobium powder) from specialty metal suppliers; Ru (Ruthenium powder) from precious metal suppliers; Sb (Antimony powder) from metal suppliers; Sc (Scandium powder) from chemical suppliers.

1. Measure each ingredient using a precision scale. 2. In a clean glass container, combine B, Nb, Ru, Sb, and Sc in the specified amounts. 3. Stir the mixture thoroughly using a ceramic or glass rod to ensure even distribution of the powders.
preparation.raw_text: 1. Measure each ingredient using a precision scale. 2. In a clean glass container, combine B, Nb, Ru, Sb, and Sc in the specified amounts. 3. Stir the mixture thoroughly using a ceramic or glass rod to ensure even distribution of the powders.

steps: 1. Preheat a high-temperature furnace to 1200°C. 2. Transfer the mixed powders into a graphite crucible. 3. Place the crucible in the furnace. 4. Heat for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction and formation of the solid compound.
heating.raw_text: 1. Preheat a high-temperature furnace to 1200°C. 2. Transfer the mixed powders into a graphite crucible. 3. Place the crucible in the furnace. 4. Heat for 2 hours to ensure complete reaction and formation of the solid compound.

steps: 1. Turn off the furnace and allow it to cool to room temperature naturally (approximately 4-6 hours). 2. Do not open the furnace during the cooling process to avoid rapid temperature changes.
cooling.raw_text: 1. Turn off the furnace and allow it to cool to room temperature naturally (approximately 4-6 hours). 2. Do not open the furnace during the cooling process to avoid rapid temperature changes.

steps: 1. Once cooled, carefully remove the crucible from the furnace. 2. Use a diamond saw or a grinding tool to cut the solid sample into the desired dimensions (3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches). 3. Sand the edges and surfaces to achieve a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, apply a sealant for enhanced durability if necessary.
post_processing.raw_text: 1. Once cooled, carefully remove the crucible from the furnace. 2. Use a diamond saw or a grinding tool to cut the solid sample into the desired dimensions (3 inches x 2 inches x 7 inches). 3. Sand the edges and surfaces to achieve a smooth finish. 4. Optionally, apply a sealant for enhanced durability if necessary.
